SENT.plain: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF(165)) is a potent angiogenic mitogen commonly overexpressed in cancerous cells
It contains two main binding domains, the receptor-binding domain (RBD) and the heparin-binding domain (HBD)

This study attempted to identify the specific sequences of the VEa5 DNA aptamer that exhibit high binding affinity towards the VEGF(165) protein by truncating the original VEa5 aptamer into different segments
Using surface plasmon resonance (SPR) spectroscopy for binding affinity analysis, one of the truncated aptamers showed a >200-fold increase in the binding affinity for HBD
This truncated aptamer also exhibited high specificity to HBD with negligible binding affinity for VEGF(121), an isoform of VEGF lacking HBD
Exposing colorectal cancer cells to the truncated aptamer sequence further confirmed the binding affinity and specificity of the aptamer to the target VEGF(165) protein

Hence, our approach of aptamer truncation can potentially be useful in identifying high affinity aptamer sequences for the biological molecules and targeting them as antagonist for cancer cell detection
